text:
SHIRLEY ZINN: I was on the
board of Cricket South Africa.
And cricket is a national asset.
We love cricket in South Africa.

And being on the board was of
great excitement even to my dad

because they had played
cricket in apartheid days

and were never given
the light of day,
regardless of their talent.

And so for me to be appointed
onto the board of cricket,
it was wow.
And I was so excited.

And I got in there, and I
saw some of the challenges

try to reconfigure things, start
to change the order of things,

try to get compliance
to the regulations done.

And I was getting
very, very worried

because all the
risks were starting
to look very, very worrying.

And I shared my
concerns with the board.

And then there were two
particular incidents.

And this is all in
the public domain.

So I'm not telling you anything
that no one else knows.

There are two things
that happened.

The first thing, the
media was barred,

or certain journalists,
their accreditation

was withdrawn on the
day of a very big match.

And there was no
authority that I

knew that had been given
to anybody to do that.
And why would anybody do that?

Why would anybody
withdraw accreditation

from journalists in the
days of freedom of speech?

And really what
was happening was

cricket was taking
a beating from media
for very good reason.

And as a key stakeholder,
you go and engage

with someone to
shift the needle,

or to nurture a
relationship, or to redirect

the narrative of
the organization
in the public domain.
But now, what do you go and do?

You bar people from
coming into a match

and reporting on it because
they write disagreeable stories.
And so that was the first thing.

And the second thing was we were
in very sensitive conversations

for director of cricket,
which is a major vacancy.

And it was very delicate
and very sensitive,

as you will appreciate, with
senior high profile people
that we were talking to.

And they were just
a few of us that
were in the know about this.

And suddenly, it was
on the front pages

of the newspaper, way before
the person had even signed

or had indicated
that they were going
to get to sign up to the job.

And I just thought that
it's such a terrible breach
of governance.

It is an embarrassing
and humiliating situation
for the organization to be in.
And this had to stop.

And I, to be on record, to
be the one to call that out,

I've never faced so much
media in my entire life.

It was completely
overwhelmed by all of it.

And so that was my
quarter four 2019,
spent on trying to deal with.

What this did was, and what
I was hoping it would do,

it would be a catalyst
for the change

that we needed to
see within cricket.
